Great to hear someone say "completely straightforward" instead of "relatively straightforward" - sums it up nicely

Hey. People asking about tutorials. On reflection, there are three that stand out in my memory as being substantially better than average. The one I mentioned during the talk is the tutorials that are part of the PyOpenGL documentation. They are ostensibly about shaders, rather than the whole of OpenGL, but nevertheless each one is a small and complete program that works, demonstrating successively more complex effects. http://pyopengl.sourceforge.net/context/tutorials/shader_1.xhtmltutorial

Finally found the third one: This one is very thorough and very highly recommended. Again, it features C/C++ code, but you can convert this into Python quite easily. "Learning Modern 3D Graphics Programming Through OpenGL"  http://www.arcsynthesis.org/gltut/index.html

Second, this 'Intro to modern OpenGL', which is much more rounded than the PyOpenGL stuff, but it features code written in C, so you'll have to do the translations into Python. Luckily, PyOpenGL makes this relatively easy. http://duriansoftware.com/joe/An-intro-to-modern-OpenGL.-Table-of-Contents.html

It was pointed out to me that 'Gloopy', my demo code, had some awful chain of dependencies. I've now removed the dependency on OpenGLContext. This also removes the subdependencies on vrml and numpy and some other stuff. Hopefully Gloopy should be easier to install and run now.
If people still have problems, feel free to post error messages here and I'll attempt to make it work for ya.
